The decision to have full diplomatic relations with the Vatican was a political move by the Reagan administration to curry favor with American Catholics. The US has had varying levels of formal relations with the Vatican for almost its entire existence. It perhaps hit its nadir - "imum" in Latin : ) - when Ray Flynn was appointed ambassador by President Clinton as a payback for Ray's campaigning in the general election (NOT the primaries.) The pope and the president always found a way to communicate, regardless of the official status of relations. This article has some of the history: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holy_See%E2%80%93United_States_relations

These preschool programs are needed precisely because many poor children are growing up in circumstances so deprived that they arrive at kindergarten unprepared to learn.

That being said, the wealthy parents who send their kids to private school first send them to two years of pre-kindergarten. The attitude of middle class parents, by way of contrast, seems to be "if it was good enough for me, it's good enough for them." This kind of reflexive conservatism is I think self-defeating.

1950 census: 5/7 black children living in an intact family.

No amount of public funds spent on the most costly per student and results-poor education system on earth will provide what's needed: parents.

"50 years ago, you only needed one income to raise a family."
That is a major part of the problem. How can parents educate and care for their children all day when they both have to work? This is not a choice for many families, but a financial necessity (especially in NYC, where rich people have driven up the cost of living to an absurd degree). Parents need a place to put their kids, and they cannot afford to pay for private nursery school. that is the sad reality. It is not due to laziness, but due to a broken social contract, where honest work in devalued. Detractors often call pre-k babysitting. Maybe is is, partially. But what should these parents do? Pick themselves up by their bootstraps and go get a job? They already have, that is the problem. Their work is undervalued. Stop that injustice, and we won't need universal pre-k. Unfortunately, I don't think decades of rising inequality will be solved overnight. So we need pre-k.

Why?

Back in teh 1960s, when I attended school on Long ISland, "pre-k" was called nursery school and teh cost was borne by the parent. You attended half day kindergarten, and then 12 years of school. This part funded by taxes. %0 years ago, school performance was much better, than what we see today. And today, it is just throw money at the problem and there is hope enough money will fix underperforming schools and the students.

50 years ago, you only needed one income to raise a family. As akid, I came home, the first thing you did was homework; something foreign to today's students. In school, you worked., or you were left back. You failed, you had summer school to make up.

Last November, we, in Colorado, were asked to riase our income taxes $1 billion a year to fund pre-k and full day kindergarten. It failed by over 2/3s.

I say this, before asking for more money to fund schools, make an effort to ibring our schools up from near last in the industrialized world. Also, you parents need to take more interest in your child's schooling. School is not a substitute for rearing child; education is suppose to happen at home, as well. This requires discipline on the teachers, parents and child's aprt. Adjusted fro inflation we spent less on schools r0 years ago, and got better results. The problem is not enough money; it is poor utilization of the money provided.

So they blithely ignore Pope Francis' message:

“Jesus wants neither selfish Christians, who follow their egos and do not speak with God, nor weak Christians, without will; "remote-controlled" Christians, incapable of creativity, who seek ever to connect with the will of another, and are not free.

Jesus wants us free, and this freedom - where is it found? It is to be found in the inner dialogue with God in conscience. If a Christian does not know how to talk with God, does not know how to listen to God, in his own conscience, then he is not free - he is not free.

So we also must learn to listen more to our conscience. Be careful, however: this does not mean we ought to follow our ego, do whatever interests us, whatever suits us, whatever pleases us. That is not conscience."

The absence of God and faith as a holder of adored virtues, reached by reason and a relentless inner search, brings us to the looking glass syndrome.

Loosely defined, the looking glass syndrome says: “Faith, truth, right, virtue, cause and effect, the order of society, the logic of thought, freedom is what I declare it to be without question or refutation, without a review of evidence—and only I and others so like-minded know what I mean when I say it. The gift of life rests in the void of my own heart. Since I believe in my own heart, I am always right and others are always wrong. "

The question should be: "Am I in Christ?"

If not, faith becomes idolatry.
And a final Matthew Henry quote (on the 4th chapter of Matthew): "They must fish, not for wrath, wealth, honour, and preferment, to gain them to themselves, but for souls, to gain them to Christ."

Matthew Henry, the Presbyterian minister, had this to say: "because he has promised to supply our wants, he should humor us, and please our fancies; because he has promised to keep us, we may expect the desired end, without using the appointed means; this is . . an abuse of the privilege we enjoy."

In other words, it is the faith--not the faithful--that has special standing! In the best tradition of Marx, these defenders have appropriated the faith and stood it on its head!
